case_name: Corporation of the City of Nagpur v. Employees

facts.text: This batch of three connected appeals raises the question whether and to what extent the activities of the Corporation of the City of Nagpur come under the definition of industry in s. 2(14) of the C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: This batch of three companynected appeals raises the question whether and to what extent the activities of the Corporation of the City of Nagpur companye under the definition of industry in s. 2 14  of the C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: The appellant is the Corporation of the City of Nagpur constituted under the City of Nagpur Corporation Act, 1948 (Madhya Pradesh Act No. 2 of 1950).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the companyporation of the City of Nagpur companystituted under the City of Nagpur Corporation Act, 1948  Madhya Pradesh Act No. 2 of 1950 .

facts.text: Disputes arose between the Corporation and the employees in various departments of the Corporation in respect of wage scales, gratuity, provident fund, house rent, confirmation, allowances etc.

anchor.surface_text: Disputes arose between the companyporation and the employees in various departments of the companyporation in respect of wage scales, gratuity, provident fund, house rent, companyfirmation, allowances etc.

facts.text: The Government of the State of Madhya Pradesh by its order dated October 23, 1956, referred the said disputes under s. 39 of the Act to the state industrial Court, Nagpur and the reference was numbered as Industrial Reference No. 18 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of the State of Madhya Pradesh by its order dated October 23, 1956, referred the said disputes under s. 39 of the Act to the state industrial Court, Nagpur and the reference was numbered as Industrial Reference No. 18 of 1956.

facts.text: The appellant filed a statement before the Industrial Court, inter alia, on the ground that the Corporation was not an industry as defined by the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a state October 23, 1956, referred the said disputes under s. 39 of the Act to the State Industrial Court, Nagpur and the reference was numbered as Industrial Reference No. 18 of 1956. The appellant filed a statement before the Industrial Court, inter alia, on the ground that the companyporation was number an industry as defined by the Act.

facts.text: On February 13, 1957, the Industrial Court made a preliminary order holding that the Corporation was an industry.

anchor.surface_text: On February 13, 1957, the Industrial Court made a preliminary order holding that the Corporation was an industry and that the further question whether any department of the companyporation was an industry or number, would be decided on the evidence.

facts.text: The appellant challenged the correctness of that order by filing a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Bombay at Nagpur, but that petition was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the companyrectness of that order by filing a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Bombay at Nagpur, but that petition was dismissed, as the award was made before its hearing.

facts.text: On June 3, 1957, the Industrial Court made an award holding that the Corporation was an industry and further that all departments of the Corporation were covered by the said definition.

anchor.surface_text: On June 3, 1957, the Industrial companyrt made an award holding that the companyporation was an industry and further that all departments of the Corporation were companyered by the said definition.

facts.text: On July 15, 1957, the appellant filed a petition in the High Court at Nagpur, questioning the validity and the correctness of the said award.

anchor.surface_text: On July 15, 1957, the appellant again filed a petition in the High Court at Nagpur, questioning the validity and the companyrectness of the said award.

facts.text: A division bench of the said High Court, by its order dated September 11, 1957, rejected the contention of the appellant that the Corporation was not an industry as defined by the Act and remanded the case to the State Industrial Court.

anchor.surface_text: A division bench of the said High Court, by its order dated September 11, 1957, rejected the companytention of the appellant that the Corporation was number an industry as defined by the Act and remanded the case to the State Industrial Court to decide the activities of which departments of the Corporation fell within the definition of industry given in the Act

facts.text: On remand, the said Industrial Court scrutinized the activities of each of the departments of the Corporation and held that all the departments of the Corporation, except those dealing with (i) assessment and levy of house-tax, (ii) assessment and levy of octroi, (iii) removal of encroachment and removal and pulling down of dilapidated houses, (iv) prevention and control of food adulteration, and (v) maintenance of cattle pounds, were covered by the definition of industry under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On remand, the said Industrial Court scrutinized the activities of each of the departments of the Corporation and held that all the departments of the Corporation, except those dealing with  i  assessment and levy of house-tax,  ii  assessment and levy of octroi,  iii  removal of encroachment and removal and pulling down of dilapidated houses,  iv  prevention and companytrol of food adulteration, and  v  maintenance of cattle pounds, were companyered by the definition of industry under the Act.

facts.text: The appellant by special leave filed in this Court Civil Appeal No. 143 of 1959 against the award of the Industrial Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant by special leave filed in this Court Civil Appeal No. 143 of 1959 against the award of the Industrial Court.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 144 of 1959 against the order of the High Court holding that the activities of the Corporation came under the definition of industry in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It also filed in this Court by special leave Civil Appeal No. 144 of 1959 against the order of the High Court holding that the activities of the Corporation came under the definition of industry in the Act and remanding the case to the Industrial Court for decision on merits in respect of each of the activities of the Corporation.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 545 of 1958 arises out of a reference made by the State Government of Madhya Pradesh in regard to the disputes between the Corporation and the employees of the Fire Brigade Department.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 545 of 1958, the third appeal in this batch, arises out of a reference made by the State Government of Madhya Pradesh in regard to the disputes between the appellant i.e., the Corporation of the City of Nagpur, and the employees of the Corporation in the Fire Brigade Department, representing themselves and other employees.

facts.text: The said reference was numbered as Industrial Reference No. 1 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The said reference was numbered as Industrial Reference No. 1 of 1957.

facts.text: The Industrial Court held that the Fire Brigade Department was an industry within the meaning of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Court held that the Fire Brigade Department was an industry within the meaning of the Act and, on that basis gave the necessary reliefs to the employees.

facts.text: In N. Banerji v. P. K. Mukherjee (1953 S.C.R. 302), this Court held that the conservancy service rendered by the municipality was an industry.

anchor.surface_text: In N. Banerji v. P. K. Mukherjee  1953 S.C.R. 302 , the chairman of a municipality dismissed two of its employees, namely, the Sanitary Inspector and the Head Clerk, and the Municipal Workers Union Questioned the propriety of the dismissal and claimed that they should be re-instated

facts.text: In Baroda Borough Municipality v. Its Workmen (1957 S.C.R. 33), the electricity undertaking of the Baroda municipality was held to be an industry.

anchor.surface_text: In Baroda Borough Municipality v. Its Workmen  1957 S.C.R. 33 . In that case the effect of the earlier decision was summarized thus, at p. 38 It is number finally settled by the decision of this Court in D. N. Banerji v. P. K. Mukherjee  1953 S.C.R. 302  that a municipal undertaking of the nature we have under companysideration here is an industry

facts.text: The State Industrial Court held that all departments except five specific ones are industries.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these departments. the State Industrial Court has held that all the departments except those pertaining to  i  assessment and levy of house-tax,  ii  assessment and levy of octroi,  iii  removal of encroachment and pulling down of dilapidated houses,  iv  maintenance of cattle pounds, and  v  prevention and companytrol of food adulteration, are industries.

facts.text: The Supreme Court holds that regal functions of the State are excluded from the definition of industry.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, exclude the regal functions of a State from the definition of industry.

holdings.text: A service rendered by a corporation, if it complies with the conditions implicit in the definition, will be an industry within the meaning of the definitions in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that a service rendered by a corporation, if it complies with the conditions implicit in the definition - which we would consider at a later stage of the judgment - will be an industry within the meaning of the definitions in the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents in Banerji and Baroda hold municipal undertakings as industry under similar definition; minor textual differences do not warrant distinction.

holdings.text: We, therefore, exclude the regal functions of a State from the definition of industry.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, exclude the regal functions of a State from the definition of industry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreed basis; regal functions are primary and inalienable sovereign powers like legislation, justice, law enforcement; supported by English and Australian precedents.

holdings.text: The former, being delegated regal functions, must be excluded from the ambit of the definition of industry.

anchor.surface_text: The former, being delegated regal functions, must be excluded from the ambit of the definition of industry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corporation as juristic person; precedents distinguish governmental from business powers; dual functions possible.

holdings.text: The definition of industry in the Act is very comprehensive. It is in two parts. One part defines it from the standpoint of the employer and the other from the standpoint of the employee. If an activity falls under either part of the definition, it will be an industry within the meaning of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The result of the discussion may be summarized thus 1 The definition of industry in the Act is very comprehensive. It is in two parts One part defines it from the standpoint of the employer and the other from the standpoint of the employee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis; inclusive definition enlarges scope; mischief rule for labour welfare.

holdings.text: The regal functions described as primary and inalienable functions of State though statutorily delegated to a corporation are necessarily excluded from the purview of the definition.

anchor.surface_text: 3 The regal functions described as primary and inalienable functions of State though statutorily delegated to a corporation are necessarily excluded from the purview of the definition.

holdings.text: If a service rendered by an individual or a private person would be an industry, it would equally be an industry in the hands of a corporation.

anchor.surface_text: 4 If a service rendered by an individual or a private person would be an industry, it would equally be an industry in the hands of a corporation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy test; non-regal services same whether by private or public body.

holdings.text: If a department of a municipality discharges many functions, some pertaining to industry as defined in the Act and other non-industrial activities, the predominant functions of the department shall be the criterion for the purposes of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: 6 If a department of a municipality discharges many functions, some pertaining to industry as defined in the Act and other non-industrial activities, the predominant functions of the department shall be the criterion for the purposes of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Predominant function test for mixed departments to advance social justice.

holdings.text: The staff of [Tax Department] doing clerical or manual work predominantly does the work connected with scavenging taxes and water rate [and is an industry].

holdings.reasoning_summary: Predominant work industrial; taxes fund services; analogy to private.

holdings.text: We hold that [Fire Brigade Department] is also an industry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Satisfies tests; private can provide; statutory powers incidental.

holdings.text: This department [City Engineers], which has administrative control over those subordinate departments [industries], is also an industry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Integrated activities; administrative part of industry.
